content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
This well-structured problem combines chemistry knowledge with regex and conditional logic skills, making it perfect for students learning both organic chemistry and programming, with clear specifications that prevent ambiguity and robust test coverage that ensures reliable implementation.

Maybe I'm missing something but how does someone infer from the statement that those functional group checks (anol, anoic acid etc.) do require (spoiler, looked at your solution) to check for the number of oxygen atoms.

You hint at it in example 3 but personally I don't think it's clear.

I see people stating the same concerns, but they validated it anyway... oh well.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproval

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like puzzles which are not artificial but coming from real life examples. This is an excellent example.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Seems like a fun one!

ooh... i notice there is not test cases to check for the suffix  {{anone}} when the {{-CO-}} is on the start or on the end of the formula? for example

input 
C2H6CO
output
OTHER 

i know the {{CO}} is wrongly put on the end but i think the code must check that scenario)

so much conditions.... 

your test cases cover a lot of possible scenarios and are very well ordered.... if you like i think you could add little more test cases to cover even more scenarios for OTHER output

more than 10 carbon:
Dodecane (C12H26)

this is still an organic compound:
Carbon Tetrachloride (CCl4)
Your statement section titled "Chemical Formulae" states that the formulae ONLY contains C, H, and O and numbers (extra parenthesis after the O). You have a few tests with N in them.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun, tests reading comprehension and takes adequately easy regex.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I don't know if it's due to my poor chemistry knowledge or that it wasn't stated, but it took me long to realize that the amount of oxygen atoms mattered in the criteria (aside from the the Alkanes and Alkenes) and kept failing testcase 26 and its validator until I decided I should finally read the examples.

That aside, I'm ready to approve it.

Bro, it was hard
You made it more hard.

Make it simpler

Note: I included two types of representations of the suffixes. Let me know which one is clearer! 

Edit: I hit the word limit in the statement so I have to remove the suffix table! If you are curious, that is what the table looks like. Note that the table below is not in monospace format. 

+------------------+---+--------+---+---------------------------+-------------+
| Compound Type    | C |    H   | O | Functional Group          | Suffix      |
+------------------+---+--------+---+---------------------------+-------------+
| Alkanes          | n | 2n + 2 | 0 | N/A                       | -ane        | 
| Alkenes          | n |   2n   | 0 | N/A                       | -ene        | 
| Carboxylic Acids | n |   2n   | 2 | Carboxyl group (R-COOH)   | -anoic acid | 
| Alcohols         | n | 2n + 2 | 1 | Hydroxyl group (R-OH)     | -anol       | 
| Aldehydes        | n |   2n   | 1 | Aldehyde group (R-CHO)    | -anal       | 
| Ketones          | n |   2n   | 1 | Carbonyl group (R-CO-R)   | -anone      | 
+------------------+---+--------+---+---------------------------+-------------+
*Note: R represents the carbon chain (alkyl group) or a single hydrogen atom.

The original problem can be found here: 
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/12158894e9b49c3611d220eccbeddfffd88743

The original problem was thought to be too difficult for clash of code, therefore, the problem was updated with more compounds to increase the difficulty. 

Aldehydes and ketones are introduced in this problem, along with identifying 'INVALID' chemical formulas that do not fit the criteria of alkanes, alkenes, carboxylic acids, alcohols, aldehydes or ketones. Players need to check the number of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen atoms, as well as whether there are additional letters that are not C, H, or O.
Do you just create a contribution based off of what you learn in school or random places?
Are you talking about the table? General formula vs functional group?
It's now a puzzle instead of a clash. Puzzles can be hard.

Good catch! 

I have included N in only one of the test case pairs (formamide and acetamide). This is used to test if the code is well-defined. 

I have changed the input statement slightly (no longer includes "... C, H and O only"). 

Under the heading Chemical Formulae, I have changed the statement to "... chemical formulae **should** only contain C, H or O and numbers" to make that clearer. 

Thank you for correcting my mistakes!
ooh... i now see the Carbon constrain

Good idea! 

Iâ€™ll implement this when I have time. 

Thanks for your suggestion.

Thank you for expressing your concern. 

The reason why I didnâ€™t include that is because I want people to think when solving the problem. It would not be fun if I just tell you straightaway thereâ€™s only one oxygen atom in alcohol, two in carboxylic acid etc. 

Additionally, in the statement, I did say thereâ€™s only ONE -OH group in alcohols which also implies that thereâ€™s only ONE oxygen atom. Same for the other compounds. 

I hope this helps answering your question. Feel free to let me know if you have any other concerns. :)
If you prefer not to explicitly state the number of oxygen atoms for each compound type, perhaps clarify that the total number of oxygen atoms should not exceed those present in the functional group.
Thanks for your suggestion! I have added this to this statement to clarify.
yea
so should I keep the table or keep the text

Answered as one of the points below.

Goal / Input
* A more specific term than "chemical formula" should be used, as it may refer to empirical formula, molecular formula, structural formula and condensed formula.

Goal
* Prefix table: Please format "n" as a [[variable]].

* Carboxylic acid: Please delete the extra "contains".

* Why is the hydrogen atom in the functional group excluded when counting hydrogen atoms in alcohols and carboxylic acids, but included when counting them in aldehydes? (If you include the hydrogen atom in the functional group, carboxylic acids contain 2n hydrogen atoms too, in addition to alkenes, aldehydes and ketones. See also comment on Example 3 below.)

* I feel that the suffix descriptions provide sufficient information, so the table could potentially be removed. However, others might find the table easier to read, so it may still be worth keeping. If you choose to keep it, please do make the columns narrower by allowing each item to span two rows, as the table in its current layout may not be shown in full in narrower windows.

* Chemical formula: Please change "it contains" to "a chemical formula contains".

* Please change "alkane, alkene, alcohol, carboxylic acid, aldehyde or ketone" to "any compound type mentioned above".

* Please change "All of them contains" to "All of them contain".

* In the example for "Alkenes vs Aldehydes vs Ketones":
  â€¢ Please use "propene" instead of "propane".
  â€¢ Please swap the order of "propanal" and "propanone".

* Final examples: Please fix the spacing so that a blank line appears between examples instead of within each example.

* Example 2: Propanoic acid is CH3CH2COOH, not CH3CH3COOH.

* Example 3: You may also mention "ethanoic acid" in the explanation for comparison, as it shares the same molecular formula (Câ‚‚Hâ‚„Oâ‚‚) as methyl methanoate.

Output
* Please add "or {{INVALID}}".

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

Everything should be fixed now. Thanks again for your help! 

Regarding the term "chemical formula", I have added the type of chemical formulae that are used in this puzzle and their corresponding definitions. Do you think that's enough? 

Also, the suffix table has been removed as I hit the word limit lol

No problem ðŸ˜‰

The revised section on chemical formulae looks good to me.

Here are two optional suggestions regarding the updated statement. Feel free to adopt them or not:

* You might consider removing the entire "Alkenes vs Aldehydes vs Ketones" section if you incorporate into the "Suffix" section that alkenes do not contain any oxygen atoms. That clarification, along with the existing descriptions, should be sufficient to distinguish them without the need for a separate comparison section.

* Regarding the output of {{INVALID}} for chemical formulae that don't match any of the defined compound types, would {{OTHERS}} be a more suitable label? The formulae themselves aren't truly invalid; they just don't fall into the specified categories.

Thanks.

I have adopted your suggestions and updated the contributions accordingly. 

Thanks once again for your help. Much appreciated!
Just thought that it would be interesting to combine coding with my knowledge in sciences.
Can I copy you, like create contributions with chemistry, because its fun to do
Yea of course you can.
THX
